Award.AwardTitle: Macroevolutionary Analyses of Cranial Morphology and Function in Mammals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mammals comprise over 5,400 species, and exhibit extraordinary anatomical and dietary diversity. It is hypothesized that the great diversity of mammalian species resulted from the evolution of structures associated with an ability to access, consume and process new food resources. However, this hypothesis has not been tested for the majority of mammal groups, and therefore the question of how mammalian diversity arose remains an important, unanswered one. This project will employ a suite of modern tools in the study of anatomy and physical forces associated with feeding (such as skull or cranial anatomy, and chewing or masticatory muscles) to test this hypothesis in three of the most species-rich and ecologically diverse mammal groups: bats, carnivores and primates. The research will generate unprecedented quantitative datasets on the masticatory muscles and the three-dimensional skull anatomy of over 100 species. The researchers will explore the links between these anatomical and functional (internal) factors with external factors (such as food characteristics and diversity) as a way to understand patterns of species diversification. Through this work, the project will create a large public database of mammal 3D cranial morphology, train a diverse group of students, disseminate results through a public museum exhibit, and establish cross-disciplinary collaborations among several young investigators.

Morphological and functional adaptations are important drivers of ecological diversification across the Tree of Life. Within mammals, it is hypothesized that many radiations were enabled by the evolution of morphological and functional traits that provided access to new dietary adaptive zones, but quantitative tests of this hypothesis are lacking for the broad diversity of mammals. This gap is partly rooted on the extensive lack of comparative datasets that integrate both the osteological and myological components of the feeding apparatus. These data, which currently exist for less than 2% of mammalian taxa, are critically needed both for an understanding of mammalian masticatory physiology and for the application of diversification analyses that contrast the relative influences of intrinsic versus extrinsic drivers of mammalian radiation. The proposed work will test macroevolutionary hypotheses about ecological diversification by generating the largest comparative datasets to date on the three-dimensional morphology, function and performance of the mammalian feeding apparatus. The team will couple micro-Computed Tomography, gross dissections, geometric morphometric analyses and biomechanical modeling to produce these data across three species-rich and ecologically diverse mammal clades (bats, carnivorans and primates). Phylogenetic comparative analyses will be used to test hypotheses about the influence of dietary selective regimes on the evolution of cranial morphology, function and performance, and their association with lineage diversification. The organismal aspect of the research will illuminate the biomechanics and ecomorphological diversity in mammal groups that are of broad scientific interest. This study will help elucidate the potential drivers of diversification in these groups while creating a foundation for further research on the physiology, biomechanics and evolution of mammal feeding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mammals have an extraordinary diversity of diets, which is thought to have been facilitated by the evolution of anatomical structures that allow them to access and process new food resources efficiently. However, quantitative tests of this hypothesis are lacking for the vast majority of mammals due to a lack of comparative datasets that integrate both the bony and muscle components of the feeding apparatus. This award combined a suite of modern tools to fill this knowledge gap in three of the most species-rich and ecologically diverse mammal groups: bats, carnivorans and primates. 

The team combined micro Computed Tomography (CT) and laser scanning, gross dissections, 3D shape analyses, and biomechanical modeling to produce unprecedented quantitative datasets on the masticatory muscles and skulls of over 200 bat, 80 carnivoran, and 100 primate species. The researchers used these data to (1) describe the variation in jaw muscle gross anatomy and internal architecture across species, (2) map the evolutionary and adaptive patterns of skull shape and jaw muscle anatomy within and among groups, (3) refine and compare methods to map anatomy and model feeding ability, (4) use biomechanical models to predict bite force differences across species, (5) link anatomical diversity of the feeding apparatus with patterns of diet and species diversity, and (6) create educational and outreach materials for undergraduates, K-12 students, and the public.

Comparative analyses allowed the team to identify size as an important determinant of the variation in skull and jaw muscle anatomy in the focal lineages, but with differences in the scaling patterns among components of the skull and jaw muscle architecture, among major groups, and among species with different ecologies. Similarly, patterns of skull shape variation appear to be influenced by the degree of integration among skull components, which differs across lineages with derived ecological and behavioral strategies. In the largest lineage examined (bats), the team identified relatively conserved patterns of jaw muscle gross anatomy, but considerable variation in muscle features that determine function across species that differ in diet. While the early evolution of skull shape differences across bats matched the evolution of echolocation use and types of sound emission, the team found that patterns of more recent skull shape evolution mirror dietary evolution within anatomically diverse lineages. Altogether, these results highlight how multiple functions have impacted skull evolution during the ecological and lineage diversification of mammals. The award also produced multiple publications that greatly detailed primate and carnivoran masticatory muscle architecture, and its relation to bite force production and diet. Additionally, the team published important findings about other regions of anatomy, which were studied in order to maximize the use of these valuable specimens.  

In parallel, the team optimized methods for quantitative comparisons of jaw muscle anatomy, including contrast-enhanced micro CT scanning. These studies highlighted that, while contrast-enhanced scans provide more accurate estimates of muscle physiological cross-sectional areas, these differ very little from those derived from dissections. This validated the use of dissection-derived PCSA data for broad evolutionary analyses. Furthermore, this grant produced several papers that documented the first digital dissections of individual muscle fascicles. This methodological advance allowed, for the first time, individual muscle fascicles to be studied in three-dimensional space. This gave new insight into their spatial relationships, especially their angularity, which is a variable that cannot be fully ascertained using traditional gross dissection methods.

By the closing date of this award, the project has produced over 30 peer-reviewed publications, two book chapters, two Ph.D. Dissertations, and 47 presentations at national and international venues. Two High School students, dozens of undergraduates, two graduate students, and three postdoctoral scholars were trained in comparative anatomy, biomechanics and evolutionary methods through this project. The research team worked with staff at the UW Burke Museum to integrate project results into the “Burke Bat Boxes”, which are traveling study kits that elementary school teachers can borrow to use in their classes. Digital models and 3D prints of skulls were also shared with educators in the US and abroad for use in teaching and outreach. Award rationale, methods, and results were disseminated to the general public via multiple presentations at public events and an interactive exhibit at the UW Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture.
